awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Engineering the thermotolerant yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus for the synthesis of biobased chemicals
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to develop the thermotolerant yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus as a platform microorganism for industrial bioprocessing. A critical area of the US industrial biotechnology sector is the conversion of biomass and other renewable feedstocks to high value and commodity chemicals. K. marxianus can grow at high temperature and low pH, and on a wide range of different sugars, important traits for economic bioprocesses. The project will develop new genetic engineering tools for this yeast and apply these tools to engineer the bio-production of two important classes of chemicals that are traditionally produced from petroleum feedstocks. The project will also contribute to the training of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as the development of new educational outreach programs for high school and community college students from diverse backgrounds.

The overall goal is to establish K. marxianus as a platform host for the production of a broad range of biobased chemicals. Critical to advancing K. marxianus is the development of new synthetic biology tools that can rapidly create strains with multiple genome edits and that can accurately control transcription of native and heterologous genes. This project addresses these challenges by (1) developing new enabling tools and methods for rapid strain development and genome engineering in this yeast species, and (2) applying the tools for metabolic engineering of pathways leading to commercially significant native (acetate esters) and non-native (polyketide) products. Phenylethyl and isoamyl acetate are valuable fragrance/flavor compounds and are used as industrial solvents. Polyketides have significant value as pharmaceuticals, including as antibiotic, anticancer, and cholesterol-lowering drugs. The rationale behind this project is that K. marxianus is a highly promising microbial host for non-aseptic (and aseptic) bioprocesses that can convert a range of different sugars into high-value and industrially-relevant chemicals and proteins. This research is transformational because it develops new synthetic biology tools and metabolic engineering approaches to harness and enhance the native traits of K. marxianus, enabling new bioprocesses for the conversion of renewable feedstocks to valuable products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
A critical area of the US industrial biotechnology sector is the conversion of biomass and other renewable feedstocks to high value and commodity chemicals. This project developed new biotechnologies to advance this industry. The stress-tolerant yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus can grow at high temperature and low pH, and on a wide range of different sugars, traits that are beneficial to designing and operating low-cost, high efficiency bioprocesses. The research of this project created new genetic engineering tools to enable the rapid design and construction of K. marxianus strains that can be used in such bioprocesses. The work of this project established new CRISPR-Cas9 based genome editing approaches for rapidly creating of modified strains, genome-wide mutational strategies for the high throughput discovery of genes related to chemical production and growth under various environmental conditions, and biosensors responsive to low-cost chemicals that enable advance bioproduction strategies that employ dynamic gene regulation. These new engineering tools were deployed to create strains of K. marxianus with improved production of two different bioesters with commercial potential – ethyl acetate and phenylethyl acetate. These compounds are naturally produced in K. marxianus and have commercial value; ethyl acetate is a widely used solvent and flavor and fragrance compounds, while phenylethyl acetate has potential for use as an alternative fuel and is also used as a flavoring agent. In addition to the research outcomes, this project helped build the US biotechnology workforce. Two students supported by this award graduated with PhD degrees, one in chemical engineering and a second in biochemistry. Two MS students also made important research contributions and were trained in advanced biotechnology skills. Together, these students helped produce six publications on the topic of engineering K. marxianus for chemical production, thus helping to establish this species as a viable host for the commercial production of biofuels and biochemicals.


Last Modified: 05/03/2024
Modified by: Ian Wheeldon
